content.question:
A two-sample <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-test for a difference in means will be conducted to investigate mean gasoline prices in two states. From each state, 45 gasoline stations will be selected at random. On the same day, the price of regular gasoline will be recorded for each selected station and the sample mean price for each state will be calculated.
Have all conditions for inference been met?

choices.label: Yes, all conditions have been met.
No, the data are not collected using a random method.
No, the sample sizes are greater than 10 percent of the population.
No, the sample sizes are not large enough to assume the sampling distribution is approximately normal.
No, the distributions of the sample data are not approximately normal.

content.answer: Yes, all conditions have been met.

topic.text: 7.8: Setting Up a Test for the Difference of Two Population Means

skill.text: Skill 4.C: Verify that inference procedures apply in a given situation.
